wordpressPost.title: Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup: 1/23/2015
wordpressPost.content:
The WeSpire Employee Engagement Weekly News Roundup aggregates the top articles from around the industry so that you can stay up-to-date on the state of employee engagement in CSR and sustainability on the go.

The Deloitte Millennial Survey 2015

Deloitte’s fourth annual survey explores what Millennials, or people born after 1982, think of business today. Employee well-being and growth and development are two areas of priority that Millennials want employers to focus on. Our favorite finding shows that Millennials want businesses to focus on people and purpose, not just products and profits.

What’s Next For CSR? Thoughts and Predictions for 2015

The author shares seven insights and trends that will re-shape how the world views businesses’ responsibility in the marketplace. The top three include personalizing employee engagement, investing in youth education, and diversity. Our favorite prediction? Expect the adoption of more sophisticated employee engagement strategies with a focus on personalization and mobilization’as well as companies embracing digital innovation to drive scale.

Different Demographic Groups Must Be Managed Differently

New research from Gallup is showing that factors such as age, generation, gender, education level and tenure all relate to a worker’s engagement, as do an employee’s job category and industry. Companies will benefit from consistently measuring and assessing employee engagement so that they can allocate resources to where engagement is most likely to thrive.

It’s Not Just Millennials: Nearly Half of Brits Want Jobs That Change the World

According to consultancy firm, Global Tolerance, 68% of Britons surveyed for its latest report think that businesses, governments, and nonprofits all need to deliver more social and environmental change. Other highlights show the increasing importance of socially conscious values in determining how people spend money, relate to companies, and choose their employment.

2015 Global 100 Most Sustainable Corporations in the World

The comprehensive list put together by Corporate Knights and Solactive is published each year and indexes the world’s top 50 sustainable brands based on a complex scoring model. Among the top 10 are Biogen Idec, Adidas, Schneider Electric, and Danske Bank. We’re proud to see that the top two are US companies (Biogen Idec and Allergan)!
